any percentage or numerical marking system.

WHY CLASS OFFICERS?
URDUE UNIVERSITY has been seriously considering the abolPishment
of class officers. The discussion was initiated by the Student Council but the matter was temporarily dropped. It is claimed
that at Purdue very little is done by the class as an organization. The
same is undoubtedly true at Hopkins. After the popularity contest,
better known as the election, the officers, with the exception of the
seniors, proceed to do nothing at all. The president of the freshman
class appoints a banquet committee as does the president of the sophomore class. The junior class leader also appoints a dance committee
and the chairman of June Week for the following year. The secretaries of the classes post one or two notices during the year. The
vice-president, treasurer, and sergeant-at-arms have no duties at all.
If the classes are to continue to have no activities as a class why
not elect the committee chairmen, and a president to supervise their
work? The other officers are superfluous, except in the case of the
senior class, and the positions of vice-president and sergeant-at-arms
would be eliminated even in the graduating class. The men who
really do the work, i. e. the committee chairmen, would thus get the
credit due them. Those who were class officers would hence be more
inclined to participate in other activities where their talents could be
put to much better use. The problem is at least worth considering.

City College, Miss Lida Lee Tall of
the University of Maryland, and
Mr. Folger McKinsey of the Baltimore Sun.

WHY CLASS OFFICERS?
URDUE UNIVERSITY has been seriously considering the abolPishment
of class officers. The discussion was initiated by the Student Council but the matter was temporarily dropped. It is claimed
that at Purdue very little is done by the class as an organization. The
same is undoubtedly true at Hopkins. After the popularity contest,
better known as the election, the officers, with the exception of the
seniors, proceed to do nothing at all. The president of the freshman
class appoints a banquet committee as does the president of the sophomore class. The junior class leader also appoints a dance committee
and the chairman of June Week for the following year. The secretaries of the classes post one or two notices during the year. The
vice-president, treasurer, and sergeant-at-arms have no duties at all.
If the classes are to continue to have no activities as a class why
not elect the committee chairmen, and a president to supervise their
work? The other officers are superfluous, except in the case of the
senior class, and the positions of vice-president and sergeant-at-arms
would be eliminated even in the graduating class. The men who
really do the work, i. e. the committee chairmen, would thus get the
credit due them. Those who were class officers would hence be more
inclined to participate in other activities where their talents could be
put to much better use. The problem is at least worth considering.
